author: xrpb11a

description.text:
By carefully adjusting the geometry in a model so that a darker color is under a lighter color by a certain number of layers, it creates a simple color blending effect.  With black and white ABS plastic, this allows about 3 or 4 shades of gray between all black and all white.  Unfortunately, the effect is minimal on the sides of objects, but on top and bottom it's quite clear.  On the side you get about 1 shade of gray between black and white.
This openscad script lets you generate test patterns.  By default, it's configured for 0.3 layer height and 1.6 width/thickness.  You'll need to modify it based on your skeinforge settings.  I bet at higher resolutions with smaller layer heights, you could achieve a greater range.
I bet you could do some really interesting blending if you used translucent PLA!  Unfortunately I don't have any 1.75mm PLA filament to test... also, I've only tried this with black and white ABS, but I'm pretty sure it would work with other colors so long as the lighter color is on top.
Note: this test object has an extra layer on top because there's currently a bug with repg dualstrusion where it doesn't print the top layer.

This is a pen holder with complex shape. The bottom part is smaller than as it extrudes it got bigger and bigger. The base size is 60 x 60 mm and the height is 80 mm. You could edit the FreeCAD file to make it bigger, but it would be hard. The easiest way is just to scale them in Cura before printing.

I used FreeCAD to design this. 
The process to make these kind of shapes is quite complex. The first thing that i did is to go to part design in FreeCAD and make 2 sketches. One for the bottom sketch and one for the top sketch which is just the bottom sketch enlarged.
After that i go to part in FreeCAD and used loft feature to make the outer part, and another loft for the inner part. Then i cut the inner part from the outer part to make the wall. After that add the base. Done !

title: EZ Clip-On Filament Guide for Feed Me!

description.text: Derived from a great key ring here on Thingiverse, the entire part is designed using the same code, just intersecting to create the necessary structure to capture the filament even without reloading it into your extruder. Place it over the edge of your Prusa Mendel printer frame (mine is from MakerGear), and it will enable your horizontally mounted filament spool to be evenly pulled by the extruder gear, just like this mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:123152

Download and print. For added stability, I would recommend an M4 bolt and matching nut in the programmed holes to place it at the top of the Prusa Mendel printer. It slips easily over the top, and any filament can be slipped into the inner circle of the "key ring" which I modified from this thing. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1378 In fact, the whole design uses modules from this thing. I cut and pasted them together to form this new design. It was fun to design with that limitation, and I think the result has a more cohesive, even organic, feel as a result.

title: Nexus 6P Desk and Car Charging Dock

description.text:
This is a dock for the Nexus 6P that can be used either on a desk or mounted in a car. The holes are designed to work on a ProClip car mount. If used on a desk, print the additional legs which lock into place. There is a hole to hot glue a USB-C cable in place. This dock was designed for use with the Spigen SGP11797 Rugged Armor Case for Nexus 6P. It would need slight adjustments for other cases, or if using no case. The dock itself can be printed without support (if your 3D printer handles bridging well), however support is needed for locking connectors on the legs if printing those. The USB-C cable used for this was the cable included with the Fi bricks Christmas present. While holding the cable bent, I hot glued it in place, and held it's position for a few minutes while letting the glue set in place. I then dremeled the hot glue smooth so that it was flat with the rest of the bottom. I also used tack putty on the bottom which holds the dock in place when I pull the smartphone out of the dock. Additional photos included. Loosely based on the Nexus 6P Dock - No Case
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1137852 Also used the NEXUS logo from Nexus 5 Dock with Charging
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1149587 Spigen Rugged Armor Case on Amazon

comments.text: it could i think. i'm not sure how cura makes supports, but most things do like a regular grid of cross hatches or lines in one direction so if it's bigger there will be more points supported. if you lookup tutorials on youtube for MeshMixer Supports, they can really help a lot. It's a program where you can click each spot where you want it supported and it makes little wire parts that go up and gently hold that spot in place, so you can reinforce any bits you think need extra. it just makes a 3d file with supports built in so you just print it in cura with the built in supports turned off and it usually works really well. it takes some practice to get good at doing it but it's super useful for things like this where the built in stuff isn't giving you the best results

title: Nema23 integrated Prusa Z with Vertex and rod clamp

description.text:
Nema23 Z axis for regular Prusa Mendel.
2 required
Integrated Vertex and rod Clamp I have some surplus/salvage Nema23 steppers that are a little too underpowered for CNC but should work fine for Prusa. I can replace 2 Nema17 steppers on my Prusa freeing them up for extruder and x-carriage on a new one. The motor should not be bolted down hard as this would cause more problems if the toolhead impacts the print(or the bed!) and allows for a little wiggle just like Prusa's original design. I used the vertex profile, so measuring and tightening the frame remains the same. Edit your frame-vertex.scad file so it doesn't produce a shape by default. I include the one I use, so edited, it's from the Prusa Felt Branch. Notice that the motor does cross the top of the z-smooth-rod. Position the smooth rod so that it doesn't quite touch the motor. This was a compromise so that spacing between the motor shaft and the smooth rod is "Standard" -- the same as with a nema 17 design. Still working on a printed coupler. But any Nema23 to 8mm coupler should work.

Copy the scad file to your Prusa build source directory before compiling, it is dependent on several of the parameters.
Put about 20mm of 12-24 threaded rod (or chopped off screw threads) in 2 holes in the Nema23 Stepper Motor on opposite corners.  Slip fit them into the holes.  Shim them with tape if they are loose as this help prevent backlash.
Edit: The 3 Threaded rods and 2 x-carriage smooth rods will have to be about 5 to 10mm longer. Mine had the extra length already.
Edit: The new STL file has been printed successfully and has the holes tightened up, perhaps a bit too much but a very light touch with a file makes them fit perfectly.

title: MakerGear M2 Narrow Motor Mount for V4 extruder

description.text:
I'm in the process of converting my MakerGear M2 to a twin-extrusion setup as developed by Tim Edwards:
http://opencircuitdesign.com/~tim/3d_printer/twin_project.html The factory printed motor mount is somewhat wider than the motor itself so you lose a bit of travel in the X-axis. MakerGear has a new all-metal motor mount which is REALLY nice, but it moves the wiring to the side you you give up even more X (only an issue in the twin-configuration). This mount incorporates what I feel are the best aspects of all the other mounts.
-It utilizes the neat new wire organizer box from the metal motor mount, but moved to the top so that it doesn't increase the width of the extruder assembly beyond the width of the motor itself. Files for wiring box available here: https://github.com/MakerGear/M2/tree/master/Printed%20Parts/STL/V4%20Hotend
-It Mounts to the front of the planetary gearbox like the metal mount eliminating the bulky pinch-clamp assembly from the factory plastic mount.
-It is quite small and uses little plastic.
I print it in ABS flat on its back at 60% infill or greater. The reason that the file is called "Metal Motor Mount" is that I had intended to cnc machine it out of aluminum, but when I 3D printed a prototype to test fit, it worked perfectly and there was no need for a metal replacement.

description.text: This is a 6DOF robotic manipulator. I worked really hard trying to use the least amount of hardware as possible. It will need 7 HiTec HS-422 servos. I've designed it and built it using these. You will be able to print, attach servos, and begin playing with it. This is kind of an advanced build but very rewarding at the same time. The arm stands approximately 35cm (around 16"). I had to do some light sanding to get the gripper to slide easily. I also adjusted roll and tilt servo mounts to exclude the need for nuts and bolts, only self tapping screws. I found this much easier than having to fight with tiny hardware for mounting servos. Please leave any comments that would help with making this project better and hope you all enjoy and someone else builds it! I posted all of the parts needed if someone wants to rebuild the model like I have. Feel free to contact me if you want the solidworks files. Thanks! ALSO PLEASE TAG ME OR GIVE ME CREDIT IF YOU USE ANY OF THESE PARTS. [email protected]

So, I spent the last year (because I work full time and go to school full time) redesigning their educational arm for 3D printing. The above model is what I personally designed to replace their metal based model.

This is a cool sphere I made by rotating 9 rings. This shape probably has a real name, but i have no idea what that might be, so please tell me if you know. It has 2 add-ons, both accessible through Customizer:
  • Hanging Decoration - This add-on adds a loop to the top to be hung as a decoration.
  • Cat Toy - This add-on adds a sphere in the center to function as a cat toy
    • I hope you enjoy printing this design!

Supports:

Yes

Notes: I printed mine with a raft (may not be necessary) and support touching the bed. I do not recommend generating support everywhere (interior) if it can be avoided. I was successfully able to remove all the support when it was generated only touching the bed, even with the sphere printed inside (CatToy-2 was tested).

The sphere is created by rotating 3 rings in the XYZ planes, and then rotating 3 of those groups 45 degrees apart. First, I used OpenScad to generate a ring using rotate_extrude() and circle(). I then used two for() loops for the rotation. One was for the rotation of the XYZ plane, and the other was for rotating the groups 45 degrees apart.

And for those of you opening it in inventor I have no idea how it became a sheet metal part, but it makes no difference when generating the stl.

mount to mount plate
wire up (i would tap into the wires going to the MK7 cooling fan)
Post pictures if you print before I do
Constructive criticism please its always helpful
Also post any changes you would like and i will make them and update.
Or change it yourself.

I wanted to create something that would make this gimbal useful to get the sweet cinematic shots everybody gets with their $300 gimbals or to a Osmo. This model has a nice grip for holding your gimbal out a car window without the worry of the very expensive GoPro flying down the road along with the gimbal tumbling down the road. I kept it slim and strong so it sorta doesn't look ugly. To power it I would recommend a small lipo or some li-ion cells from batteries since the gimbal is not a power hog. remixed_from.title: Fallout Joe 2 – a T-45d Power Armor Action Figure

description.text:
I was having trouble slicing the original model with slicer, so I ran it through a program the original author told me about and was able to get them all fixed up and slicing.  Posting here for others to use.
Update:  I've added plates of the NCR and BOS versions of the armor.  These plates have each piece oriented in the best way that it prints for me.  The goal was parts that are strong enough to not break when putting the figure together while allowing for the easiest to remove support material.  You will need supports and likely a brim/raft.  I used a 5mm brim (might be excessive but it worked).  When it's done, you'll want to use some pliers and an exacto knife to remove the support.  Once the support is removed it should fit together nicely. 
If any parts are slightly loose, you can use some clear nail polish to tighten the joint.  The only piece I could never find a satisfactory orientation for was the lower torso/waist.  As designed, it is supposed to allow for waist twist.  In the orientation I have the plates at, the joint to the upper torso will most likely break.  I've found no good way to orient this piece that makes it strong enough for the pose-ability it offers and still is easy enough to clean the supports away from.  It would be stronger lying flat, but it makes the sockets for the legs very messy/difficult to clean out without breaking the surrounding real material.  So I've settled for simply super gluing the waist in place.

Use an m3 screw tap for the yoke and use low profile panhead m3 screws to attach to the cans

author: AnthonyQ

description.text:
Build an American Civil War era ironclad warship then sail it into the battle. The design and construction of steam powered ironclad warships was in its infancy during the Civil War. Engineers tried modifying wooden ships, and building ironclads from scratch, with varying degrees of success. It was difficult to find the right balance between armor, firepower, and speed. In this project students can try their hand at designing an ironclad warship, 3D printing their vessel, then test it in battle. All the parts for building Civil War ironclads are included here and can be downloaded and assembled. But a much easier way to do this is to open the Civil War Ironclad Construction Kit on Tinkercad.com and assemble the parts there.
https://tinkercad.com/things/0RVPhhX8Cew Several historic examples are included here and in the PDF directions. Ironclad models can be printed with or without bases. This project is based on one created by Peter Pellegrino for the JuniorGenral.org website. Peter's rules use paper ship models for the Battle of Mobile Bay (1864). The model forts are for anyone that wants to use Peter's original rules from the website.
http://www.juniorgeneral.org/naval/mobile%20bay/mobile%20bay.html

The easiest way for students to build their ships it to search for and open the file Civil War Ironclad Construction Kit on Tinkercad.com.  All the parts are in that file and students just need to move them into the correct position and then delete the extra pieces to have a printable model. Models can be made with or without the base and name tag.
Students will want to use the arrow keys to help them move parts into the correct position. They will not need to resize the pieces or lift them off the workplane. Pieces can be copied or duplicated as needed. The only rotating that might be needed is for the ends of the casement.

description.header: Project: Civil War Ironclad Construction Kit
description.text:
Objective Students will design and print an American Civil War ironclad warship and test it in battle. Audience This project is intended for grades 6 - 8. Younger students can complete the project but will need an adult to help them with the rules during battle. Older students can run the battle portion on their own. Preparation Students should have a basic understanding of the American Civil War and would fit well near the end of a unit on that subject. The 3D design process using Tinkercad is relatively easy and would be a good project for beginners. Steps
  • Download the Designing an ironclad warship PDF file for full details on the project
  • Use the rules to choose the characteristics of your warship
  • Go to Tinkercad.com and find the Civil War Ironclad Construction Kit file and open it https://tinkercad.com/things/0RVPhhX8Cew
  • Assemble the parts to make your warship, delete the extra parts
  • Download and 3D print your warship or an entire fleet
  • Set up a battlefield and use the rules in the PDF file to battle you friends
    • Results The rules have been playtested with students in grades 6 - 8 using paper models.

I liked xifle's original tumbler tag concept - I've played around with different ways to mark glasses in the past and this seems like a great solution. But I don't have a lot of colors of filament handy. So, why not emboss a symbol of some kind onto the tags as well? With four colors and four types (three symbols + blank), you can keep track of 17 glasses, which is more than I own. This thing gives you a few pre-made symbols (peace sign, yin-yang, and heart) in two sizes that work well for me with thin and thick tumblers, respectively. You can use those as is, or use the Customizer to upload your own image and make a new symbol.

The default settings in the Customizer are for the "small" tags, which work on the glass pictured in the photo. The "large" tags were done with a Glass Max of 4 and a Glass Min of 1.8.  
I used grayscale images with some blur added in Photoshop to make the supplied models; if you have a sharp contrast between black and white you'll get a harder edge on the embossing, which you might prefer but may print poorly.  
Note that the Customizer preview often looks pretty rough; I don't know what to do about that. The models look fine once you download them.

description.text:
I make a lot of projects that use 3/8" aluminum tubing and one of the things I hate is that it is sold on 50ft. rolls.  Which doesn't help much if you need straight pieces.  So I made this roller to be part of a 3D printed tubing straightner.  However, the base undured too much strees and flexed too much to make a usable tool.  So I wound up using a piece of 3/4" plywood.  This works better than anything that I have tried up to this point.  It still leaves an ever so slight arc in a 3ft piece of tubing, but it can easily be worked out by hand, or by rotating the tubing in the rollers while you move it back an forth.
This roller can also be used for other 3/8" tubing and rod projects, so I decided to put it on Thingiverse to see what others make of it.

To make a tubing straightner:

  • Print out 3 rollers. Be sure to clean out loose plastic in the bottom beariung hole. I use needle nose pliers and a flat head screw driver. There may be a better way to print this so that the plastic does not ooze down there while the roller is printed, but I am new to 3D printing and this is only my second custom made print.

  • Press in the bearings. The rollers are designed to use 3/4" x 25" roller skate bearings. I pressed each bearing in with a bench vise. Tap it in with a hammer should work if you don't have a bench vise.

  • Mount the rollers on the plywood. I used 5/16" bolts (same ID as roller skate bearing). The closer you mount the rollers, the more stress each roller endures. I found that by mounting 2 close together and a 3rd one out a little bit works the best(as shown in the picture). YOu will need to experiment and find the best measurements that work for you.

title: Polar Alignment Jig for Meade Equatorial Mount

description.text: I wanted to use a green laser to help me rough align my Meade Equatorial Wedge.  So, I created a jig that slips in the hole and holds my laser pointer.

Designed the model in SolidWorks 2013 and exported it as an STL file.  Printed on my MakerBot Replicator 2X with ABS using standard settings, modified to 100% infill to increase strength and minimize flexing.  
I included alignment holes for the laser, but didn't end up needing them.  I had to do some filing on the OD to make it fit snugly into the Wedge.  Other than that, it worked great.

description.text:
This was a 7th grade project in a computers / writing class. 
Our school is on a barrier island that often has flooding problems, particularly during storms like Hurricane Sandy.
The students researched ways that homeowners and communities can protect themselves from flooding. The students then used Tinkercad to design and print a structure that would be helpful in a flood situation.
One student example is shown.
NGSS

This was a 7th grade project in a computers / writing class. 
Our school is on a barrier island that often has flooding problems, particularly during storms like Hurricane Sandy.
The students researched ways that homeowners and communities can protect themselves from flooding. The students then used Tinkercad to design and print a structure that would be helpful in a flood situation.
One student example is shown.

• Use the Internet to research ways people deal with the threat of coastal flooding
  • Use Tinkercad to design a structure
  • Print structures
  • Write a description of the structure you designed, and an explanation of how it will work to protect the community from flooding.

Objective Imagine your community has been devastated by a flood that resulted from a storm larger than Hurricane Sandy. Design a system (including public works projects, such as bulkheads, seawalls, dune modifications or street/sewer improvements) or building that will restore the community and protect the individuals or community from future flood-causing storms. Audience This was a 7th grade project, but could work for grades 5 - 9 Preparation The students had done research on the ways communities have dealt with the threat of flooding. Students had limited experience with Tinkercad.com Steps
  • Use the Internet to research ways people deal with the threat of coastal flooding
  • Use Tinkercad to design a structure
  • Print structures
  • Write a description of the structure you designed, and an explanation of how it will work to protect the community from flooding.
    • Results The students successfully designed structures including dams, drains, sea walls, and raised buildings.

description.text:
I saw the lack of quick to print clothes pegs on the thingiverse. The one i did see was the old school wooden peg design. I wanted something simple and quick to print. So i made this, i would say its the bare essentials needed for a peg.
I printed them in PLA on my Dremel 3D printer. I printed 4 and it took around 24 minutes with minimal structure in side (10% hex). They have been outside in the Australian sun for a few hours now and no sign of melting or flexing from the heat.

author: christensendayc

description.text:
The original bracket by Alekseev_D made the bottom of my belt rub on the bottom rod (using a 608 bearing), so I created this variant to move the bearing up a bit.  4mm up was enough for me.  I also created the attached belt clamp spacer (a variant on Prusa's belt clamp file) to move the belt attachment point up 4mm to make it so it will pull absolutely straight.  It's also parametric so you can make the spacing different.
This allows mounting the bottom Y carriage "upside-down" which gives more Z travel by utilizing otherwise wasted space under the printer.  This also eliminates one 608 bearing and the associated nut and washers.  It does add one bolt.  In all the vitamin count is reduced including one bearing.
EDIT: I wound up not using this configuration because I have an oversized pyroceram (high temperature glass) print bed which collides with my triangle vertices when the print bed is mounted this low.  I also am at the limit of my threaded rod and can't widen the chassis any more without replacing all the rod.  I still believe that this is a viable configuration and I may widen the printer in the future, after I finish assembly and get this printer working.
Just be aware that you may have similar issues if the print bed is dropped down this much.

The included STL should work for the standard Prusa design.  If you need the spacing to be different, use the SCAD file.
Both SCAD files rely on files in the Prusa branch (configuration.scad and functions.scad) so if you need to make one other than the STLs I include here, you'll have to put it in the directory with your Prusa parts.
Note that the spacer includes teeth to engage with the belt and they're set up for XL belt.  If you're using T5, set the tooth spacing to 5 instead of 5.08mm.

title: Clip-together phone stand, fast printing, portable

description.text: I wanted a simple, lightweight phone stand/cradle, I tried the one by mjengland but it took a while to print and was solid.  I simply removed the upright "peg" and made a clip-in foot design for it. Now you can print both parts flat on the print-bed (quicker), it's also more portable because the parts are flat.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

20

Notes: Print it at whatever resolution you like, I used 0.4mm nozzle, 0.1mm layer height at 45mm/s print speed. No support required, no raft. Simplify3D for slicing (sequential printing; object-by-object).
Shouldn't need any clean-up, just clip the two parts together, first use may require a bit of force.

title: Flat Pack Fastenerless (FPF) Game Table With Reversible Top

description.text: This 24" high game table is intended to be cut from a 2x4' panel of 3/4" stock material such as plywood or MDF.  The legs slot together and the top is secured between tabs at their upper corners.  The reversible top might be painted with, say a chessboard on one side and a backgammon board on the other.

This .dxf file contains ideal part profiles, which is to say that these ARE NOT tool paths, because they do not account for the kerf of your cutting tool.  I assume you have the capacity to make appropriate corrections for your mill.  Certain profiles, such as the bottoms of the legs and the edge of the table top, are shared between multiple parts to minimize materials wastage and other factors.  It is impossible to correct these profiles for kerf, but error here will affect only the tightness of fit of the table-top.  The distances between the tabs that restrain the top could be reduced to compensate for any "rattle" that might result from a wide kerf.

comments.text: I don't actually have a CNC mill yet, unfortunately.  And I'm not reallysure of the utility of posting ideal part profiles.  It feels like I should be posting tool paths.  I guess it gives people ideas, even if they can't just download it straight to the mill and run it.  But since I don't have a mill I don't know what kerf to assume.  1/4" maybe? Is that pretty standard?  It occurred to me after I posted this that you could correct for kerf errors on the inner legs/tabletop perimeter cut by taking ALL the kerf out of the legs and none of it out of the round table top piece.  It doesn't matter if the legs are a bit thinner, of course, but the table top really ought to be nominal diameter.

description.text: This is a case for spare spark plugs.  It was made for spare plugs for a snowmobile.  This case protect the spare plugs and can be put in a glove box.  The case has 3 parts, the bottom, top and a plate.  The spark plugs screw into the plate and the plate is enclosed between the top and bottom of the case.  The plate will secure the plug and keep the plug from rattling inside the case.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: The bottom is printed bottom down, the top is printed top side down, and the plate is printed flat. On the plate there is a slight taper in the prongs in the holes, the side with the long end of the taper should be printed down. I included pictures of the top and bottom on the printer bed. No supports are needed.

Screw the plugs into the plate.  The plate should fit inside the case top.  If it fits tight, scrape the edges with an exacto knife, or file the edge so it fits easily into the case top.  The plate will be sandwiched between the case top and bottom when the case is closed.

I made a model of a spark plug based on dimensions found on the internet.  I made the case to fit around the model of the plug.  I then measured an actual plug for a snowmobile and adjusted the size of the case holes so it should fit about any size plug.
I was considering putting some foam in the top hole to keep the plugs from rattling inside the case.  I came up with the plate that the plug screws into.  This plate could be designed into the bottom of the case, but I decided to keep it a separate part so it will be easy to remake another if the tabs get wore out or broken off with use.
The 123D design file is included if you wish to make changes.

This object is basically the Nexus 5 bike mount by Ramdac, but I replaced the phone cradle arms with a holder based on the Nexus 6 Cradle by Davross. I still need to get the 4x M3x20mm + nuts to actually attach it to my bike, but it seems to fit my Haanjo, despite a few discrepancies from printing it with my printrbot maker's kit. edit: my local hardware store only had M3x16mm screws, so I have uploaded a new model that works with those (the "_16mm" files). I think this design sacrifices some ease of installation, but seems to remain sufficiently strong. It stood up to a 45 minute ride with no issues. Will upload an image soon.

This is my TTS tool holder which is designed to prevent them from rattling together in my tool drawers. the holder has interlocking dovetails on the sides so that it can be stringed together . The holder has a stippled base to increase the chance of printing successfully and reduce the chance of warpage in the finished part by reducing tension in the base layers. I have only had one failure of this part when I tried printing it to fast. so I recommend printing the part at slow settings with a infill of 10-20% and 3 shells. The model has also been hollowed out in strategic places to reduce the total filament used. to see the part in action visit:

author: NT_Toys

description.text:
4-10-2016
Changing the Lyman/Mullier into a faster and easier to use extruder, also trying to make it cheaper then the original Lyman. Tested it at speeds till 3000mm/min or 10 feet/min for 3.00mm filament, currently around +/-0.2mm but believe that can be improved. Wrote new firmware to use a Arduino DUE and a TFT Touch screen. It's not longer using the RAMPS/MEGA. The Filament sensor was also rebuild, it's using a Teensy (for the moment) and can measure the filament width ~1200 times/second. It's also not sensitive anymore to outside light except direct sunlight. Firmware includes the audit-trail function as was included in the Mackerel firmware. A windows app is available to log the data for further analyses. Work in progress! so it will change! In fact this is the 5th prototype. It's vertical because the data shows that the filament consistency is better then with a horizontal version. 29-12-2016
Added image of the sensor feedback

description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays EDIT: Updated version on YouMagine: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/recorder-music-instrument It works! It finally works! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F9VdXtTlhCU This revision includes minor tweaks which necessitated breaking it into 4 parts. Thank you nycdesigner, tbuser, and landru for your helpful suggestion, guidance, and sticking with me til the end. The recorder is one of the oldest woodwind instruments. In the hands of an experienced player it creates a sound synonymous with Renaissance music. Often used in elementary music classes because of it's ease of operation. With 3D printing everyone can have one of their own to make beautiful music on... or wailing screeches if they never got past "hot crossed buns".

• Print recorderv2.2.stl with high infill. (Alternately you can print the individual parts.)

  • Sharpen the edge of the lip to a fine point.

  • Assemble.

  • Twist the foot to adjust for comfortable pinky finger placement.

  • The top of the body and the mouthpiece is connected with a longer connecter to allow for some tuning.

  • Note that if you start with all holes covered and remove them one-by-one that the high notes are going to sound flat. That is normal. To get the proper tones for all the notes use the key chart on en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recorder#Recorder_fingering .

comments.text: Thanks!  I am really struggling to create a brim.  I feel like such a newb... I have tried a lot of different software packages and it seems like Meshmixer is a good one, but I can not seem to figure out how to make a raft.  Any suggestions for tutorials?
comments.author: Panoreth

comments.text: A brim is an auto-generated structure from the slicer to aid in adhesion. This is just a solution to a symptom and not the actual cause of your problem. As Panoreth mentioned, having a level bed is extremely important. If the first layer is too high off the bed, than it will not stick very well. Watch the first layer go down and make sure the hot end is placing plastic DIRECTLY on the bed and not dropping it some distance (even half a millimeter can be too high). Having a heated bed also helps, but this is one of those things you either have or you don't have, so in lieu of that, try using an adhesive like an Elmer's glue stick or very strong hairspray. Either of these two adhesives, combined with a level bed, should alleviate most of your problems.
comments.author: ahsScience

title: Pack More! Ikea FIXA Drill Box mod

description.text: Pack more items into your IKEA FIXA Drill box. I threw out the moulded orange insert which only held the drill, power adapter and set of screws. Pretty big waste of space IMO. Adding a smaller FIXA screwdriver and adapter plus drill bits, flexi chuck heads, hex screwdriver set was fine until I threw in a manicure drill (to file PLA prints). While it was still relatively easy to retrieve items, putting them all back in each time was becoming a pain. These clips are designed to help organise the box to fit all these photographed components into the box (or on the cover). All clips are mounted with a pair of M38mm screws, except for the flexi chuck on the cover, held on by 4 M36mm screws. Reverse drill bits, screwdriver heads are held on with double-sided tape. The power adapter holders are designed for EU 2-pin plugs. I've added the Sketchup files for these so feel free to mod away.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Support used for power adapter holders, none for the other parts.

Design was ground up, by placing all the items in the most optimal way for access (regular items first). Then braces or holders were marked over paper, transferred to Sketchup drawings. Mounting is a tad difficult for the base because you cannot really see the screw holes. Solution is to place the part, mark an outline with pencil, then a piece of tape or PostIt over the part, tracing over the shape and punching through over the screw holes. Reverse over the pencil mark made on the box, mark holes and drill through. Drilling done in 2 parts, first with a 1mm drill bit, then a 3mm bit to open it up, making it easier to screw the M3 screws onto the parts.

description.text:
Only simple addition to v4, added a nut slot that can be dropped from the top but the slot are somewhat fixed to have m4, you can however use the openscad script to change the screw hole size for other screws including the e3d lock, but the size of the nut slot/pit there might remain unchanged. The code to change this manually is at line number 118 to 127 in the openscad file, you might want to try out the presets first on top. No picture of the real thing, but I am currently using the v3 as of now and it is working ever since, this is just an update to v3 Those who're willing to update my code, can do so in here
https://github.com/sarf2k4/Customizable-GTech-Parts/tree/master/groove%20mount But please make some notes of the changes, and do a pull request for changes that are 'destructive' method

About the Objects All of the objects except the one tagged with v4 in their filename are defaulted to m4 screws like in v1 and v2, to customize them is to download all of the file, stl files included for the openscad to modify on to your liking The only object that can be used directly is
  • gtech gmount v4 top/btm.stl
  • fasteners
  • e3vlock
  • fastener servo
    • all of the objects listed above can be used directly but with default to M4 as stated above. the top.stl and bottom.stl acts as a base to generate the variable screw holes Changelog
  • Only added the nut trap/pit in for easier nut access thus requiring shorter screws
  • Added 2 types of fastener blocks, M for 36-38mm M3, L for 50mm M3 screws
  • Slightly modified the nut trap slightly larger to reduce resistance of nuts going in
  • The customisable script will soon be deprecated because of some issues in making them compatible with each other
    • Next update expected
  • may not be for bowden drive anymore (I had filament jam when teflon inserted and nozzle not seasoned that time, unknown as of after seasoning the nozzle)
  • adjust the mounting for the servo to adopt the shorter screw required to mount extruder to fastener
  • the scad file will be deprecated

comments.text: For your comments on all metal hotends and PLA, the biggest problem is the hot end getting too hot above the heat break. If it gets warm enough to get the filament close to glass transition temp, the filament deforms and jams. The easy solution is to always run a fan across the cooling fins above the heat break. High-quality hotends like the E3Dv6 come with a cooling fan for this very reason.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/btbLzFpbQGz

This is a forced cooling enclosure i created to suit the Gen 6 electronics.
The fan duct is glued onto the main cover as im too lazy to change it to a snap on, plus glued could have several advantages. The cover snaps onto the base and a 40mm fan is attached to the fan duct.
This creates a wider higher pressure flow of air for cooling in the important places. It provides good forced cooling keeping the board cool.

Print all 3 parts.
Mount base under Gen 6 PCB
Glue fan duct to main cover
Mount fan
Snap cover onto base.
Connect all electrical connections on Gen 6 board.

description.text:
Many 3D printer parts and gadgets need a ton of screws and nuts.
Every time I want to work on my printer I have to search for tools in my garage - and I hate this!
So I created a small knob for M3 nuts. Now I am able to release this nuts without any tools. This is very useful for nuts which have to be opened often. This gadgets is tested with M3 nuts from DIN 934. It should work with other nuts too.
Maybe you need a small drop of glue (depending on print quality) to secure the nut in the knob. I am using this knobs for my Anroid IP camera quick release mount or my extruder mount for example. See pictures :)

remixed_from.author: ehsanpro
remixed_from.title: Adjustable belt tensioner X or Y

description.text:
Found a belt tensioner that I kind of liked on Thingiverse but it wasn't quite suited for my needs so I made a copycat in Studio Max.  
This has two options for the main body, one with full cylinders and one with half cylinders.  The half cylinder occupies less space obviously if that's a concern while the full cylinders give you maximum strength if you really need to crank it down. 
Additionally there are lips on the pieces to keep it from slipping off the belt. 
It uses an M3 bolt and nut since I have a lot of those and should be an snug fit although there is a slight allowance for expansion.

Printer:

MendelMax 3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

30%

Notes: Nothing special required, the minor overhangs on the main body piece are ramped enough that I think it would print fine on most printers. Mine had no issues with them.

comments.text: There are not bearings.  This isn't designed to ride on a belt but to be placed on a single side of a belt.  The belt fits between the fixed and adjustable surfaces then the adjustable part is screwed in which adds a ( bend to the belt.  The more you screw in the part the deeper the ( and thus the more slack that is taken out of the belt.

This is a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1148116 by daozenciaoyen, and adds an extra phone_count parameter to hold more than one phone.

A LED lighting solution for the print bed / print head.
This uses an adhesive strip of LED's which run at 12Vdc so you can connect them to a cooling fan supply etc. The LED's are cleverly made so you cut the strip on the line marked in modules of 3 and they only cost $2.95 per 3 LED segment. I used two strips of 3 LED's and then stuck them with the adhesive backing and a tiny amount of silicone to the underside of the travelling x axis carridge. Also comes with free printable trolley coin for pupping in the grocery trolley at the supermarket instead of using a $1 or $2 coin.
(Because i had to add a file that wasn an image to publish)

Purchase LED strip module from electronics supply store.
I got them from Jaycar CAT. NO. ZD0473.
http://www.jaycar.com.au/productView.asp?ID=ZD0473&form=CAT2&SUBCATID=976#1 Cut LED strip into 3 LED segment on the line.
Solder supply wires onto the LED strip at the correct marked points.
Affix LED's in a suitable location.

comments.text: You can get the light strip very cheap from hobbycity. A meter for $4.89 which is 60 LED's.
comments.author: billyzelsnack

description.text:
Spare Part for the Turnigy 1/18 Stadium Truck 118B.
The stock parts are way too weak and the bone-links will slip through after a short time.
Spare parts are not sold solely (only with the whole differential).
So I decided to build some stronger parts.
Made in ABS - Maybe some Acetone vapor will make them even stronger This version works fine, if I makle it on my 3D Printer - needs maybe some customizations on yours?!

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.19

Infill:

full

Notes: I printed them "on the side" with very little support and "smart bridging", so only support under the object needs to be removed.
